text: Klaxons surfing the void I salute you
sergeant whiskers of the seventh kitty
astronaut division hello my needle drops
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd about to get into an
album review Klaxons surfing the void
this band isn't too unlike their UK
contemporaries like foals or these new
Puritans very experimental songs with
dancey beats but Klaxons sophomore LP is
a lot louder and a lot beefier to the
dance aesthetics that made their 2007 LP
so immediate are here but this thing is
a little more serious seriousness here
guys whether it's the sound quality or
just the really compressed mix keeping
most of the instruments just at the same
volume the overall feel here is very
very smooth there are some really great
beats on this LP but the volume here
does not give you any room to dance or
breathe for that matter and it's not
hard to see why because producer Ross
Robinson was behind the board's on this
one and he's of course also done
production for corn and beer factory and
and Slipknot but don't get me wrong
Klaxons do not go new metal on this LP
but the sound is a lot more aggressive
from pitchfork to new Musical Express
tons of critics have said Klaxons are
difficult to define many of them kind of
being maybe a little lazy and falling
back on the new rave tag that has been
dubbed to them and I wouldn't really say
Klaxons are reinventing the wheel
they're definitely not what's so good
about Klaxons is that they never drive
down one road or stick to one style long
enough to let it define them so if
you're looking for an album that refuses
to be pigeonholed then this may be where
you want to look because you've got
really heavy grooves distinct vocals
psychedelic effects abstract lyrics
about cosmic claptrap and when I list
out these things I'm just thinking in my
head damn sounds like an awesome album
let me have that album but truth be told
I don't
like this album yeah some tracks are
real winners for me like the opening
single echoes or the track of anusha but
most the production is so heavy that it
literally kills off the dynamics throws
a plastic bag over their head ties it
off and just suffocates them to death
which is sad because it's clear Klaxons
worked very hard on writing verses and
choruses that have a lot of contrast to
them volume wise arrangement wise but
when this LP actually gets loud most of
the time for me it just sounds like a
big bowl of mush with maybe the
exception of the track flashover which
embraces the volume of this album with
some really heavy distorted riffs I just
feel like Klaxons on this album have
written 10 ninjas but they ended up with
like nine and a half sumo wrestlers I've
read in numerous places that this LP is
actually a rewrite of an album that
Klaxons handed their record label
Polydor and then Polydor was like no way
bro that's way too experimental I'd like
to hear those tracks and if they come
out in the future I will let you guys
know whether or not I dig them but as is
this album I really do not care for it
and it has nothing really to do with the
experimentation and the adventure of it
in fact that's kind of why I respect
Klaxons and that's pretty much where my
ears are on this album but let me know
where yours are on this thing are you
loving it are you hey Ned and and why
I'm feeling a light for to a strong
three on this thing and it's not

nore seriously don't you know it

whoever Klaxons target audience is for

and that's pretty much how I'm going to
